I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) to promote innovative financing 
for key ecosystem protection and restoration (EPR) projects.1 The TA will support policy advice, 
propose financing options for selected EPR investments, and facilitate knowledge sharing on 
innovative market-based financing of EPR investments.2 The TA complements ADB’s support to 
the PRC in ecological compensation and green finance. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Many years of accelerated growth have enabled the PRC to become an upper middle-
income country and the world’s second-largest economy, eradicating extreme poverty, and 
developing  modern  physical  and  economic  infrastructure.  The  country’s  unprecedented 
development progress has, however, come at a cost to the environment. The environmental 
challenges arising from the rapid economic expansion have disproportionally affected the low-
income  population  and  vulnerable  ecosystems.3 In  this  regard,  the  efforts  on  biodiversity 
conservation, which are vital for sustainable development and rural revitalization, can have 
significant direct impacts on human health. This has become particularly important given the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.4 
 
3.  Cognizant of the importance of an increased focus on protecting the country’s environment, 
the government has moved toward building an ecological civilization—a concept rooted in the 
belief that people must live in harmony with nature.5 In this context, progress has been made in 
improving  vegetation,  soil,  and  water  quality  of  the  ecosystems  mainly  through  eco-
compensation—the government’s major market-based mechanism to finance green development 
at central and provincial levels.6 Despite the progress, the level of investment in natural capital 
remains inadequate to reverse the trend of environmental degradation. In this regard, it is 
important to increase social capital investment (private firms, state-owned enterprises, collective 
farms, international financial institutions) in natural capital to diversify the funding sources, 
augment the government’s funding, and create incentives for behavior changes to achieve 
desirable outcomes for ecosystems.7 
 
4.  Accelerating  green  and  low-carbon  development  and  strengthening  ecological 
conservation is a policy priority of the government, which has also adopted policies to promote

new funding sources and innovative financing solutions for public investments, including in EPR.8 
In 2020, the government adopted a 15-year master plan on EPR (footnote 1), which promotes 
innovative and diversified investment, facilitates the emergence of long-term multi-stakeholder 
funding  mechanisms  for  EPR  projects,  and  envisages  that  EPR  projects  should  promote 
greenhouse emission reduction for eventual carbon emission trading.9 The PRC’s National 
Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) is the government’s lead agency responsible for 
implementing the EPR master plan. 
 
5.  Efficient and effective realization of the EPR master plan’s agenda to scale up social 
capital investment in EPR is constrained by (i) insufficient mechanisms and policies for value 
realization of ecosystem products and services;10 (ii) a weak enabling environment for innovative 
EPR  investment  financing,  mainly  attributed  to  the  lack  of  an  operational  framework  and 
guidelines to value ecosystem products and services as investment assets and to incentivize 
private investment in such assets; (iii) a lack of a pipeline of innovative finance EPR projects 
because of the weak capacity in financial structuring of such projects and inadequate knowledge 
on funding options; and (iv) an overall weak awareness on innovative financing of EPR projects 
because of a lack of knowledge sharing. The TA will help the NDRC address these constraints. 
 
6.  The TA is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 3 and ADB’s 
Climate Change Operational Framework 2017–2030 and is aligned with the strategic priorities of 
ADB’s PRC country partnership strategy, 2021–2025.11 The TA will complement and build on 
ADB’s comprehensive past and ongoing support to the PRC in eco-compensation and green 
finance. Based on the One ADB approach, the TA will promote innovation by providing policy 
advice  on  new  ways  of  catalyzing  private  finance  solutions  for  EPR  projects,  including 
investments related to nature-based carbon sequestration.12 The TA’s findings may inform the 
programming of ADB’s sovereign and nonsovereign operations in the PRC. The TA is also 
expected to have a replication potential in the PRC and in other developing member countries 
(DMCs).

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA will be aligned with the following impact: social capital investment in EPR projects 
increased (footnote 1). The TA will have the following outcome: policies and management on 
innovative13 finance for EPR investment improved.14 
 
8.  The TA will focus on EPR projects in the Ningxia, Yunnan, Jiangxi, Zhejiang, and Jilin 
provinces that come from the EPR master plan, including in preparing preliminary business cases 
for selected EPR projects in these provinces. The selection of the provinces is to enable 
consideration of different ecological protection and economic development contexts to enable the 
TA’s policy advice to be relevant for various parts of the PRC. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Innovative financing solutions for ecosystem protection and restoration 
investment promoted. Based on EPR specifics of the selected provinces, output 1 will support 
the preparation of policy-oriented research papers on promoting innovative financing of EPR 
investments and EPR-related carbon sequestration. The research on carbon sequestration will 
be synchronized in time with the workplans of NDRC on carbon sequestration and neutrality 
activities.15 The research papers will be based on the review of (i) the national and provincial 
frameworks on EPR, public investment, and investment financing;16 (ii) the viability of EPR 
products  and  services  as  investment  assets;  (iii)  the  supply  and  demand  sides  of  such 
investments (including incentives and constraints);17 and (iv) the applicable international best 
practice.18 
 
10.  Output 2: Options on innovative ecosystem protection and restoration investment 
financing proposed. Output 2 will support the preparation of five preliminary business cases for 
attracting debt and equity financing for selected EPR projects, including suggestions on the 
catalytic  support  from  ADB  at  project  level  and  to  develop  EPR  funding  schemes  and  
instruments.19 Among possible funding instruments and schemes could be environmental impact 
bonds, domestic biodiversity investment funds, and partnerships with multinational or global funds 
related to EPR and carbon emission reduction.

11.  Output  3:  Knowledge  on  innovative  ecosystem  protection  and  restoration 
investment financing enhanced. Output 3 will support capacity building and consultation events 
on innovative financing solutions and funding schemes for EPR projects (including reducing 
emissions from deforestation and forest degradation, plus the sustainable management of forests, 
and the conservation and enhancement of forest carbon stocks [REDD+] projects) and on multi-
stakeholder consultations on the financing of selected EPR projects.20 Output 3 will also support 
(i) study tours of NDRC staff to learn from successful experiences on innovative EPR financing 
and EPR-based carbon sequestration,21 and (ii) preparation of knowledge products on innovative 
financing of EPR investments in English and Chinese—to share findings and recommendations 
within the PRC and with other ADB DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $660,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), $150,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Special Fund,22 and $150,000 will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund.23 The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space and supplies, secretarial assistance, venues for activities, information and communication 
facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA  through  the  Public  Management,  Financial  Sector,  and 
Regional Cooperation Division of the East Asia Department. The Rural Economy Department of 
NDRC will be the executing agency for the TA. The implementation arrangements are summarized 
in the table.

improved livelihoods and jobs, and ocean ecosystem health. Source: The World Bank. 
21  Indicatively, up to three study tours (domestic or foreign) will be conducted. Study tour destinations will be

the study tours will be presented in consultation events and in the knowledge product under output 3. If the study 
tours are not possible because of prolonged COVID-related travel restrictions, webinars and other modes of virtual 
knowledge sharing and communication will be considered, as applicable.

(i) vehicle purchases, and (ii) salaries for civil servants.

combination with other government, donor, and commercial funding; (iv) supporting cooperation for science and 
technology to facilitate transfer of technology, knowledge, and experience; (v) building the capacity of market actors 
in the context of implementing climate change investments and programs; (vi) commercializing and replicating new 
climate change finance instruments; and (vii) supporting other nonlending measures, i.e., policies, regulations, 
standards (national, regional, and local), and institutional capacity building.
